name: aspirin
desc: A commonly found OTC medication. Commonly found as a pill or chewable.

indc.desc: Asprin is indicated for patients with chest pain. Contraindicated for patients with a GI bleed, coagulation disorder or G6PD deficiency. Use caution when administering to women who are pregnant or breastfeeding or children under 12.

name: Topical Hydrocortisone
desc: A common OTC topical steroid often found in squeeze tubes or spray bottles.

indc.desc: Indicated for patients with itching and rashing, particularly due to insect bites. For external use only. Do not cover with a bandage unless directed by a doctor.

name: Albuterol
desc: Most commonly administered via MDI or nebulizer. May be used for patients with asthma or COPD.

indc.desc: Indicated for patients with bronchospasms. Contraindicated for patients with a history of hypersensitivity to albuterol.

name: Ondansetron
desc: Can be administered via IV or PO. Used to treat nausea and vomiting.

indc.desc: Indicated for patients with nausea or vomiting, particularly those due to surgery or chemotherapy. Contraindicated for patients with long QT syndrome, Apomorphine, Cisapride, Dofetilide, Dronedarone, Levoketocanazole, pimozide, thioridazine.

name: Oral Fluids & Electrolytes
desc: Often come in powder form and are mixed with water. Used to treat dehydration.

indc.desc: Indicated for patients with dehydration. Contraindicated for patients with GI or airway obstructions or issues and unconcious patients.

name: Bandages, Tourniquets and Hemostatic agents
brandnames: QuikClot, Combat Gauze, Israeli Bandage, CAT, SOF-T
desc: Comes in rolled, gauze, or powdered form. Used to stop bleeding.

indc.desc: Indicated only for patients with major uncontrolled bleeding. Use caution and moderation when using powdered hemostatic agents. Tourniquets may cause damage to the distal limb if left on for >2 hours.

name: Oral glucose
desc: Comes in gel or liquid form. Candy may also be an acceptable substitute.

indc.desc: Indicate for patients with hypoglycemia. Contraindicated for patients who are unconcious or unable to swallow. Use caution when administering to patients with a history of diabetes or hyperglycemia.
